Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Novel Bimanual Upper-body Exoskeleton for Stroke Therapy
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is that the project addresses one of the most critical and challenging problems in stroke rehabilitation - shoulder and arm rehabilitation. More than 800,000 people suffer from a stroke per year in the US and most of them are left with arm and shoulder impairments. This robotic invention has the potential to deliver revolutionary benefits to these stroke survivors, including better recovery outcomes and shorter length of hospital stay. Indirectly, the innovation will improve vocational skills and prevent consequential safety accidents after a stroke. The major outcomes of this work has the potential to improve the rehabilitation outcomes of not only stroke patients but also those with upper extremity neurological and musculoskeletal impairments. The project will create a unique opportunity for exposing the PI and researchers to the process of translating basic research into deployed technology.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will validate the capability of the proposed rehabilitation robot technology for correcting abnormal coordination of the shoulder complex after stroke. Although rehabilitation hospitals have long sought a technological innovation that will lead to a higher clinical efficacy than conventional care, there is no robotic intervention commercially available that fully addresses the shoulder rehabilitation problem. The PI and collaborators will validate the proposed design and controller with experiments with human subjects. The planned experiments will confirm the proposed robot technology that addresses the abnormal shoulder coordination problem, which is critical for the shoulder rehabilitation after stroke. In addition, PI and collaborators will define and develop a minimum viable product (MVP) of the proposed innovation which will confirm the product-market fit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stroke is one of the most serious health care problems in the US that leaves millions Americans disabled and results in billions of dollars in treatment costs. Current treatment options have failed to recover stroke patients resulting in severe disabilities, especially in shoulder and arm movements. While robotics is a promising technology for delivering effective therapies, currently there is no robotic system that can positively affect a subject’s shoulder movement. Our team has developed one of the most sophisticated exoskeletons, called Harmony, for upper limb rehabilitation. The exoskeleton wraps around the subject’s both shoulders, arms and wrists, and has the ability to move the user’s shoulder complex through its natural mobility.

During the NSF SBIR Phase I project, Harmonic Bionics has tested the technical feasibility of shoulder therapy for stroke patients and also validated the commercial feasibility of Harmony. We conducted experiments of Harmony with healthy subjects. The results confirmed Harmony as the first rehabilitation robot which addresses the abnormal shoulder coordination problem, which is critical for the shoulder rehabilitation after stroke. In addition, we defined and developed a minimum viable product (MVP) of Harmony which confirms the product-market fit. The accomplishment of the aims confirmed both the technical and commercial feasibilities of Harmony, which is a critical step toward commercialization before an NSF SBIR Phase II award. 

As Harmony is successfully commercialized, more than 650,000 stroke patients may get benefits from our innovation, and these will include higher functional and motor outcome and shorter length of hospital stay. Indirectly, our innovation will improve vocational skills and prevent the consequential safety accidents after a stroke. The major outcomes of this work hold incredible potential to improve the rehabilitation outcomes of not only stroke patients but also those with upper extremity neurological and musculoskeletal impairments.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Stroke is one of the most serious health care problems in the US that leaves millions Americans disabled and results in billions of dollars in treatment costs. Current treatment options have failed to recover stroke patients resulting in severe disabilities, especially in shoulder and arm movements. While robotics is a promising technology for delivering effective therapies, currently there is no robotic system that can positively affect a subject?s shoulder movement. Our team has developed one of the most sophisticated exoskeletons, called Harmony, for upper limb rehabilitation. The exoskeleton wraps around the subject?s both shoulders, arms and wrists, and has the ability to move the user?s shoulder complex through its natural mobility. During the NSF SBIR Phase I project, Harmonic Bionics has tested the technical feasibility of shoulder therapy for stroke patients and also validated the commercial feasibility of Harmony. We conducted experiments of Harmony with healthy subjects. The results confirmed Harmony as the first rehabilitation robot which addresses the abnormal shoulder coordination problem, which is critical for the shoulder rehabilitation after stroke. In addition, we defined and developed a minimum viable product (MVP) of Harmony which confirms the product-market fit. The accomplishment of the aims confirmed both the technical and commercial feasibilities of Harmony, which is a critical step toward commercialization before an NSF SBIR Phase II award. As Harmony is successfully commercialized, more than 650,000 stroke patients may get benefits from our innovation, and these will include higher functional and motor outcome and shorter length of hospital stay. Indirectly, our innovation will improve vocational skills and prevent the consequential safety accidents after a stroke. The major outcomes of this work hold incredible potential to improve the rehabilitation outcomes of not only stroke patients but also those with upper extremity neurological and musculoskeletal impairments.
